questions.text: A 26-year-old child came to OPD with a belly button rash. It is slightly itchy and uncomfortable when wearing pants. What is the potential agent for the same
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Nickel allergy The given clinical scenario and the picture is suggestive of Nickel allergy. Nickel is the most common metal cause of allergic contact dermatitis. Source of nickel: Jewellery and metal components of clothing: Prolonged contact with skin Coins, keys, scissors, knitting needles, thimbles, scouring pads and other metallic tools and utensils: Transient but frequent Platers and some metal machinists: risk of occupational nickel allergy. Features: Patches of dermatitis at sites of contact with metal objects Most commonly, the ears from earrings, Wrists from watches and bracelets, Neck from necklaces and their clasps, Central back and upper chest from bra components, Central abdomen from studs and zips in trousers, especially jeans, and Dorsa of the feet from shoe buckles.

Highyeild:

Allergic contact dermatitis A Type IV hypersensitivity (delayed type) reaction occurs to a substance (allergen) in previously sensitised individuals by the same molecule. A photo patch test is done for diagnosis Common substances are known to cause Allergic contact dermatitis Chromium in cement Pallidum Gold PPD in hair dye PTBP in Bindi Vegetable matter

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option Permethrin allergy: Permethrin is an insecticide used as a topical cream for scabies and other parasitic infestation. It can cause skin irritation, itching, swelling and redness. Option B. Potassium dichromate: Most exposures to chrome are occupational, from cement in construction workers. Option D. PPD allergy: Paraphenylenediamine is used in hair dye responsible for contact dermatitis.

questions.text: A 6-month-old male has had a rash for the past 4 weeks and it is getting worse. They applied over-the-counter drugs but they were of less help. No other rash or no mucosal complaints were there. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Irritant contact dermatitis The given clinical picture is of Diaper dermatitis, a type of Irritant contact dermatitis. Diaper dermatitis: Develops in prolonged and too frequent contact with degraded urine or faeces. It occurs most frequently in young or elderly individuals with urinary or faecal incontinence. Complicating factors: Sweat , occlusion, irritant cleansers, secondary medications and secondary infection. Features: Dry and fissured skin, restricted to the site of contact Burning and pain o ften present Treatment: Frequent changes in absorbent napkins in infants Improve continence in elderly Emollients Barrier cream Topical steroids and antibiotics

Highyeild:

Allergic contact dermatitis Irritant contact dermatitis Cause: Immunologic- Type IV hypersensitivity reaction Non-immunologic- Direct tissue damage Predisposition: Affects all genetically predisposed individuals Affects all those who are exposed Site: Disseminated Restricted to the site of contact Symptoms: Itching Burning and pain

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B. Allergic contact dermatitis: It is a type IV hypersensitivity reaction characterised by vesicles and bullae instead of dry and fissured skin, as in irritant contact dermatitis. Usually, it occurs on exposed areas of the skin. Option C. Acrodermatitis enteropathica: It is characterised by chronic diarrhoea and fatty substances in faeces(steatorrhoea). In the congenital form, symptoms start gradually, frequently during wearning. Option D. Pellagra: It shows peeling, redness, scaling and thickening of sun-exposed areas, often as Kassals necklace. It is caused due to niacin deficiency in the diet.

questions.text: Treatment of atopic dermatitis includes any of the following except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Isotretinoin Isotretinoin causes dry skin due to its sebolytic effects. AD patients already get dry skin. Hence, isotretinoin would further worsen them.

Highyeild:

Treatment of atopic dermatitis A) General therapy- Barrier repair—Very important to address dryness of skin (xerosis) and an impaired epidermal barrier. This is done by applying moisturizers (Petrolatum and ceramide based moisturizer) B) Specific therapy- First line Second line Third line (Systemic) · Topical steroids · Topical calcineurin inhibitors (Tacrolimus/pimecrolimus) especially in areas prone for steroid induced atrophy (e.g. face, flexures) ·Phototherapy · Steroids · Azathioprine · Mycophenolate mofetil · Cyclosporine · Methotrexate

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with eczematous dermatitis over the extensor surfaces. His mother has the history of bronchial asthma. What should be the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Atopic dermatitis Atopic dermatitis typically presents with eczema lesions on extensors loke cheeks and elbows in children. H/o bronchial asthma also supports this diagnosis.

Highyeild:

Hanifin and Rajka criteria for diagnosis of AD Major criteria (Must have 3 of the following) Minor criteria Must have 3:*Only the important ones have been mentioned here 1. Pruritus—HALLMARK of the disease 1. Dennie-Morgan infraorbital folds—linear transverse crease under lower eyelid 2. Typical distribution: – Flexural in children and adults m/c site is antecubital fossa, knee flexures – Facial and extensor involvement in infancy—m/c site is face 2. Ichthyosis (dry skin)/hyperlinear palms (increased skin lines) 3. Chronic relapsing dermatitis 3. Elevated serum IgE 4. Personal or family history of atopic disease (asthma, allergic rhinitis,atopic dermatitis) 4. Hand/foot eczema 5. Dry lips and inflammation (Cheilitis) 6. Xerosis (dry skin) 7. Pityriasis alba- Presents as poorly defined, hypopigmented, slightly scaly patches on the cheeks, typically in children/young adults

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B- Air borne contact dermatitis (phyto-photodermatitis) is due to chemicals in plants which can cause a phototoxic reaction on exposed parts of skin (phyto = plant, photo = light) Option C- Seborrheic dermatitis is an inflammation and scaling in seborrheic areas due to Malassezia. It shows greasy, yellow scales. Option D- Discoid eczema will have coin shaped eczematous lesions.

questions.text: The feature shown in the Image is seen in:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Atopic dermatitis The given image shows “ Dennie Morgan fold ”, which is an ocular abnormality of Atopic dermatitis. Ocular abnormalities of atopic dermatitis: Dennie –Morgan fold : It is an extra fold of skin under the lower eyelids Keratoconjunctivitis Keratoconus Cataract Retinal detachment

Highyeild:

ATOPIC DERMATITIS Key diagnostic criteria: Hanfin and Rajka Pruritus- hallmark Rash on face, extensors, or both in infants and young children Lichenification in flexural areas in older children Tendency toward chronic or chronically relapsing dermatitis Personal or family history of atopic disease: asthma, allergic rhinitis, atopic dermatitis Other Common Findings: Skin features: Dryness Ichthyosis Pityriasis alba White dermatographism (white line appears on skin within 1 minute of being stroked with a blunt instrument) Head-light sign : periorbital, perioral and perinasal area are spared Ocular features: Dennie-Morgan folds (accentuated lines or grooves below the margin of the lower eyelid) Allergic shiners (darkening beneath the eyes) Conjunctivitis Keratoconus Anterior subcapsular cataracts

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B. Seborrhoeic dermatitis: These are Greasy, scaly yellow patches over the scalp, nasolabial folds, eyebrows. Option C. Allergic contact dermatitis is a type IV hypersensitivity reaction characterised by vesicles and bullae. Usually, it occurs on exposed areas of the skin. Option D. Irritant contact dermatitis: Inflammatory, localised skin response caused by a broad range of physical or chemical agents. It occurs in all those exposed and is restricted to sites of exposure.

questions.text: White dermographism is seen in?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Atopic eczema White dermatographism occurs due to capillary vasoconstriction following light stroking of the skin occurs normally but is particularly pronounced in atopic eczema.

ATOPIC DERMATITIS Key diagnostic criteria: Hanfin and Rajka Pruritus- hallmark Rash on face, extensors, or both in infants and young children Lichenification in flexural areas in older children Tendency toward chronic or chronically relapsing dermatitis Personal or family history of atopic disease: asthma, allergic rhinitis, atopic dermatitis Other Common Findings: Skin features: Dryness Ichthyosis Pityriasis alba White dermatographism (white line appears on skin within 1 minute of being stroked with a blunt instrument) Head-light sign : periorbital, perioral and perinasal area are spared Ocular features: Dennie-Morgan folds (accentuated lines or grooves below the margin of the lower eyelid) Allergic shiners (darkening beneath the eyes) Conjunctivitis Keratoconus Anterior subcapsular cataracts

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B. Urticaria: Shows cholinergic or symptomatic dermographism Option C. Angioedema: It is characterized by swelling that occurs beneath the skin's surface, usually in the face, lips, tongue, throat, or genitals. It is often caused by an allergic reaction or a genetic disorder. Option D. Lichen Planus: It is a chronic inflammatory skin condition that typically presents with flat, itchy, and shiny bumps or lesions that can occur anywhere on the skin or mucous membranes.

Extraedge:

Types of Dermographism: Type of dermographism Seen in Feature White dermographism Atopic Eczema Occurs due to capillary vasoconstriction following light stroking of the skin Cholinergic dermographism Cholinergic urticaria A type of dermographism that occurs in response to an increase in body temperature, such as during exercise or exposure to heat. The skin becomes raised and itchy, and small red bumps may appear. Symptomatic dermographism Physical urticaria Characterised by itching or burning skin sensations and the development of pruritic wheals and flare in areas exposed to shearing forces on the skin. Black dermographism Discolouration of the skin after pressure from a metallic object

questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above Atopic dermatitis is classified as endogenous eczema triggered by exogenous agents.

questions.text: Patch tests are used for diagnosis of:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Contact dermatitis Patch test is used to identify exogenous allergens in ACD (confirmatory test for ACD), not in endogenous eczema like atopic eczema. Patch strips are prepared by putting a drop of the allergen onto aluminium chambers (Finn chambers) and then stuck onto upper back The patches are removed after 48 hours and 3 readings are taken 3 readings—Immediately after removal of patch (i.e. 2 days), next at day 4 (best reading time), and Day 7 for late reactions (for metals, PPD and neomycin). Red papules, edema and vesicles at a particular area indicates ACD to that chemical.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B- Seborrheic dermatitis is a common inflammatory skin disease presenting with a papulosquamous morphology in areas rich in sebaceous glands, particularly the scalp, face, and body folds. Option C- Atopic dermatitis is an endogenous eczema where patch test would not help Option D- Nummular eczema is also called discoid eczema of coin shaped eczema. Disc = oval or circular, “oid” = like. Hence, circular, or oval plaques (like a coin) of eczema with a clearly demarcated edge

questions.text: True about atopic dermatitis are all except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Microabscess Microabscess is seen in psoriasis/cutaneous lymphoma/dermatitis herpetiformis, not in atopic dermatitis (AD). Psoriasis has neutrophilic microabscess in epidermis. T cell cutaneous lymphoma has lymphocytic microabscess in epidermis. DH has papillary microabscess.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A- Pruritus (itch) is a classical symptom in AD Option B- Exudation (oozing) occurs in AD due to underlying spongiosis. Spongiosis refers to the presence of fluid in between keratinocytes in the epidermis. Option C- Lichenification refers to the presence of thick, black skin with increases skin markings in AD. This occurs due to constant rubbing and scratching.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child with since last 4 weeks mother notices many rounded, oval or irregular hypopigmented patches that are not well marginated. Lesions are often slightly erythematous and have fine scaling. No atrophy could be appreciated in the examination. Diagnosis:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pityriasis alba Pityriasis alba It is a low-grade type of eczema mainly seen in children. (Pityriasis = fine scale, Pale colour = hypopigmentation) Age: Children and adolescents 3 to 16 years, girls = boys. Site: In children, they are often confined to the face, most commonly on the cheeks and around the mouth and chin. In 20% of affected children, the neck, arms and shoulders are involved, as well as the face. Can also occur on trunk Features: The individual lesion is a rounded, oval or irregular hypopigmented patch that is usually not well marginated. Lesions are often slightly erythematous and have fine scaling. Initially, the erythema may be conspicuous , and there may even be minimal serous crusting. Later, the erythema subsides completely and at the stage at which a physician commonly sees the lesions, they show only persistent fine scaling and hypopigmentation. 5 to 2 cm in diameter, but they may be larger, especially on the trunk.

Highyeild:

Eczema: Reaction pattern of the skin secondary to the internal or external stimuli

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B. Vitiligo is an autosomal dominant autoimmune disease of adults with depigmented lesions. The lesions show absent melanocytes in histology. It occurs due to the generation of autoimmune antibodies against melanocytes. Option C. Nevus depigmentosus: It is a pigmentary disorder due to defects in the transfer of melanosomes from melanocytes to keratinocytes. Option D . Leprosy: It is caused by infection of M . leprae . Disease after infection depends upon the host's Leprosy can present with hypopigmented patches with decreased sensation and atrophy. In histology, there are acid-fast bacilli detected.

Extraedge:

Classification of the principal forms of eczema Exogenous eczemas: Allergic contact eczema Endogenous eczemas: Asteatotic eczema ● Dermatophytid ● Eczematous polymorphic light eruption ● Infective dermatitis ● Irritant eczema ● Photoallergic contact eczema ● Post‐traumatic eczema ● Atopic eczema ● Chronic superficial scaly dermatitis ● Eyelid eczema ● Hand eczema ● Juvenile plantar dermatosis ● Nummular dermatitis ● Pityriasis alba ● Metabolic eczema or eczema associated with systemic disease ● Seborrhoeic eczema ● Venous eczema

questions.text: An 83-year-old male was admitted to hospital for a flare of his chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) in winters. After 1 week, he complains of some itchiness in his lower legs. The crazy‐paving pattern is seen on the leg. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Asteatotic eczema The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Asteatotic dermatitis. It is aka eczema craquelé, a common type of dermatitis due to dry skin. Sites: Shins (most common) can occur in the upper limbs and trunk. Cause: Mainly due to water loss from the stratum corneum Low humidity Excessive use of soap and detergents Age: Elderly people Predisposing factors: Ichthyosis, thyroid, malnutrition, retinoids Features: Distinctive crazy-paving appearance: Diamond-shaped plates of skin are separated from each other by red bands forming a network. It may flare during winter due to a reduction in humidity associated with central heating. Treatment: Emollients, moisturisers, topical steroids

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Photodermatitis: It is characterised by a pink or red skin rash with blisters, scaly patches or raised spots on areas directly exposed to the sun. The lesions resemble eczema, but it occurs on exposed surfaces in areas exposed to light. Option B . Paederus dermatitis: It is an irritant contact dermatitis characterised by the sudden onset of erythema bullous lesions on exposed areas of the body caused by insects of genus Paederus. Accidental brushing against or crushing the beetle over the skin causes a release of its coelomic fluid, which contains a vesicant agent called paedrin. Option D. Seborrheic eczema: It is a papulosquamous disorder with distribution on the sebum-rich areas of the scalp, face and trunk. Its severity ranges from mild dandruff to exfoliative erythroderma.

questions.text: A male presents with a palmar rash that has troubled him remittently for the past 2 years. It is worse on the right and, when troublesome, the affected skin fissures and is painful. The blisters tend to burst. No other parts of the body are affected. The most likely diagnosis and treatment for the same is?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hyperkeratotic hand eczema - emollients The given clinical scenario and the picture is suggestive of hyperkeratotic palmar dermatitis It is a form of eczema in which there is thick scaling on the palms. Age: Middle age, Males> Females Cause: Idiopathic , classified as endogenous eczema Features: Sharply demarcated, hyperkeratotic, and fissured lesions in the middles of both palms. Starts in one palm and progresses to involve the other palm and velar surface of the fingers. Fissures are often painful No vesicles or pustules Nails are not affected Treatment: Emollients , Topical steroids

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B. Psoriasis-puva: Although the features of both the conditions are similar, psoriasis involves other sites and nails are also affected. Option C. Ringworm (tinea manuum) - antifungals: It is a fungal infection of the hands. There is a red laque with an active vesicular scaly border and a centrifugal growth. Palmar surfaces may have a dry scaling appearance. Option D. Tylosis – salicylic acid: aka hyperkeratosis palmaris et plantaris. It is characterised by focal thickening of the skin of the hands and feet and is associated with an increased risk of squamous cell carcinoma of the oesophagus.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy had itchy, excoriated papules on the forehead and the exposed parts of the arms and legs for 3 years. The disease was most severe in the rainy season and improved completely in winter. Most likely diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Insect bite hypersensitivity Insect bite hypersensitivity (IBH) is a hypersensitivity reaction to insect bites. It tends to be symmetrically distributed, itchy papules and papulovesicles. It is often seen on exposed parts of extremities, increases in monsoon.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B- Scabies will not have lesions only on the exposed skin. Also, seasonal change would not be seen. Option C- Urticaria will have wheals as the classical lesion. Option D- AD has eczematous eruptions on flexures (adults) and extensors (children)

questions.text: A male complains of increasingly severe dandruff and an itchy rash on the face. No other area is involved. No significant history of previous disease. He has been prescribed a steroid cream, which provides only temporary relief. What is the Diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Seborrhoeic dermatitis The given clinical scenario and the picture are suggestive of Seborrhoeic dermatitis. The picture shows rash affecting areas of high-sebum production (nasolabial folds).

Highyeild:

Seborrhoeic dermatitis: It is a common, chronic, or relapsing form of eczema/dermatitis Age: Biphasic incidence occurring in infants and in adolescents and adults Site: Mainly affects the sebaceous gland-rich regions of the scalp, face, and trunk. Pityriasis capitis: (dandruff) Uninflamed form of seborrhoeic dermatitis on the scalp. It has a predilection for the cutaneous folds, including large flexures and submammary areas, and the distribution is usually symmetrical. Cause: Unknown, but commensal lipophilic yeasts of the genus Malassezia have long been associated with SD.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Herpes – orofacial: It is characterised by superficial ulcerative lesions of the tongue and surrounding oral mucosa. Painful perioral vesicles are present overlying an erythematous base. Option B. Allergic contact dermatitis: It is caused by chemical exposure. It commonly occurs on the exposed areas like hands, feet etc., at the exposure site. Pruritus is the predominant symptom associated with vesicles and bullae. Option C. DLE: It is s characterised by initial dry red patches, which then form red plaques with adherent scales. It may progress to atrophic scarring and scarring alopecia. Lesions are present on the nose, cheeks and ear lobes.

questions.text: Airborne contact dermatitis can be diagnosed by:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Patch test A special form of patch test called photo-patch test is done for air borne contact dermatitis. It is used to detect chemicals which get activated by sun exposure (photo-allergens). Here chemicals are applied in patches on both sides of back. Halfback is irradiated with UVA, other half covered. If the exposed site becomes positive indicates photo-allergic eczema.

Highyeild:

Air-borne contact dermatitis (ABCD)/ Phyto-photodermatitis: Chemicals in plants can cause a phototoxic reaction on exposed parts of skin (phyto = plant, photo = light) A combination of Type 1 and Type 4 hypersensitivity is postulated Parthenium hysterophorus (congress-grass)—a plant-weed of family Compositae grows freely in Indian farms (commonest cause of plant dermatitis in India). The release of sesquiterpene lactone (SQL) by the leaf, stem and pollen of these plants causes ABCD in farmers Chronic itching, scaling, lichenification is seen on eyelids (air allergens can lodge in eyelids initially), face, nasolabial folds, V-area of the chest. More in summers, less in winters Diagnosis is by photo-patch test Oral steroid is the DOC for acute management and Azathioprine is the DOC for long-term immunosuppressive management

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B- Skin biopsy is not required as patch test is the method of choice for diagnosis Option C- Prick test is done for urticaria where food allergens are pricked into skin and wheal formation as the site indicates the suspect food culprit for urticaria. It is a type 1 hypersensitivity response. Option D- IgE is high in many diseases, not only in eczema.

questions.text: An adult presents with itchy hyperpigmented plaque with exudation on the flexure of the elbow and back of knee as shown. The diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Atopic dermatitis Oozing lesions on flexure is strongly s/o atopic dermatitis. In adults, lesions are seen on flexures, while in young children, they are seen on extensors

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A- Psoriasis has extensor area lesions. They are scaly and erythematous. They do not have oozing Option C- Dermatitis herpetiformis has itchy, vesicular lesions on extensor elbows with gluten intolerance. Option D- Pemphigus has blisters on skin with oral involvement (pemphigus vulgaris). Nikolsky sign is positive

questions.text: A 45-year-old farmer has itchy erythematous papular lesions on the face, neck, 'V' area of the chest, dorsum of hands and forearms for 3 years. The lesions are more severe in summer and improve by 75% in winter. The most appropriate test to diagnose the condition would be?

options.label: B
options.text: Estimation of IgE levels in blood

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Patch test The patient is suffering from photoallergic contact dermatitis. And the most appropriate test for diagnosis is the Patch test.

Highyeild:

Patch Test It is undertaken to investigate and confirm substances that produce Allergic contact dermatitis. Relies on the principle of type IV hypersensitivity reaction. Method: A series of allergens are applied to the back The allergens on the patch include latex, medications, preservatives, hair dyes, fragrances, resins and various metals. It needs to stay for 2 to 4 days Positive result: shows erythema & papules or vesicles After 48 hours, the patch is removed, and erythema is noted Another read is taken after 96 hours to check for any delayed reaction. Photopatch test Modification of patch test Done for photo allergen

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Skin biopsy: In the case of Photoallergic Contact dermatitis , the diagnosis is usually made based on clinical presentation and history of sun exposure. Option B. Estimation of IgE levels in blood: Can be done but Photo Patch test is a better option. Option D. Intradermal prick test: It is used to diagnose IgE-mediated allergic reactions, such as those that occur in response to insect venom, pollen, or certain foods.

Extraedge:

Important consideration for patch test Patch test should be delayed for 4 weeks after sunbathing Steroids should be stopped before test (but at doses <15 mg no effect of steroids on the test)

questions.text: A 15 year old presents with well defined pruritic round oozing lesions as shown. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Nummular dermatitis The given clinical scenario is suggestive of nummular dermatitis or discoid eczema. The diagnostic lesion of nummular dermatitis is a coin‐shaped plaque of closely set, thin‐walled vesicles on an erythematous base.

Highyeild:

Nummular dermatitis It is common eczema defined by scattered, well-defined, coin-shaped and coin-sized plaques of eczema. Cause: Unknown. But often associated with Staphylococcal aureus infection Precipitating factors: Localised injury (scratch), insect bite, impetigo, dry skin Features: Affects limbs Often bilateral: After any period of between 10 days and several months, secondary lesions occur, often in a mirror‐image configuration on the opposite side of the body which is characteristic. Exudative acute discoid eczema: oozy papules, blisters, and plaques Dry discoid eczema: subacute or chronic erythematous, dry plaques

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Tinea corporis: It is a fungal infection characterised by Annular scaly patches with central clearing and peripheral extension, the periphery may be studded with pustules seen commonly in the groin, trunk, axilla and face. Scraping with koh mount shows mycelia Option C. Psoriasis: It is a papulosquamous disorder characterised by well defined erythematous plaques with silvery white scales predominantly over extensors. Auspitz sign positive. Option D. Pityriasis rosea: It presents with the history of a herald patch and characteristic oval patches with long axes parallel to the ribs. It usually follows a viral
